document.docTitle: Prochristianella scholzi Schaeffner & Beveridge, 2012, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Prochristianella Dollfus, 1946 (Trypanorhyncha: Eutetrarhynchidae) from elasmobranchs off Borneo and Australia, including new records and the description of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Prochristianella Dollfus, 1946 (Trypanorhyncha: Eutetrarhynchidae) from elasmobranchs off Borneo and Australia, including new records and the description of four new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type-host:
Taeniura lymma
1 ( sensu
Naylor et al . 2012
) ( Rajiformes : Dasyatidae ) (KA- 416 ).
Additional localities: Semporna, Sabah, Malaysia ; and Tanjung Batu, East Kalimantan, Indonesia .

Deposited specimens: Holotype ( MZUM No 2012.01 ). Paratypes in ( MZUM Nos 2012.02 â€“03; MZB Nos Ca 165â€“167 ; LRP Nos 7829â€“7834 ; SAM Nos
AHC 35395
â€“35399; and USNPC No 105183 ).
Etymology: This species is dedicated to Dr. TomÃ¡Å¡ Scholz, who has contributed previously to trypanorhynch systematics.

Description: Cestodes small; mature specimens 3.6 â€“6.0 ( 4.9 Â± 0.8 ; n = 10 ) mm long with 7â€“9 ( 8 Â± 1 ; n = 15 ) segments; gravid specimens 6.5 (n = 2 ) mm long with 9 (n = 2 ) segments. Scolex acraspedote, 950â€“1,465 ( 1,240 Â± 153 ; n = 13 ) long (
Fig. 9
A, D); maximum width at pars bothrialis, 280â€“330 ( 306 Â± 18 ; n = 8 ) wide; pars bothrialis 150â€“220 ( 180 Â± 21 ; n = 13 ) long; two sub-circular bothria, 175â€“200 ( 188 Â± 10 ; n = 7 ) long, 205â€“240 ( 219 Â± 10 ; n = 11 ) wide, with thick, free margins, notched posteriorly, V-shaped ridge present in some specimens (
Fig. 9
A); pars vaginalis 450â€“920 ( 716 Â± 138 ; n = 13 ) long; Pintnerâ€™s cells present in mid-line (
Fig. 9
D); tentacle sheaths sinuous to almost straight, strongly coiled if contracted; transverse striations present in pars vaginalis (
Fig. 9
A, D); pars bulbosa 470â€“590 ( 520 Â± 38 ; n = 13 ) long, 165â€“225 ( 194 Â± 18 ; n = 13 ) wide; prebulbar organs present; bulbs elongate, thick-walled, 455â€“570 ( 506 Â± 38 ; n = 11 ) long, 60â€“80 ( 70 Â± 5 ; n = 11 ) wide (
Fig. 9
A, C, D), extend into pars proliferans in some specimens; bulb width: length ratio 1.0: 6.3â€“9.3 ( 7.4 Â± 0.9 ; n = 11 ); retractor muscle inserts at base of bulb; gland-cells present, few, very small (
Fig. 9
C, D), surrounding retractor muscle to mid-bulbar region, in some specimens into anterior third of bulb; scolex ratio (pars bothrialis: pars vaginalis: pars bulbosa) 1.0: 2.6â€“5.5 : 2.4â€“3.7 (1.0: 4.0 Â± 0.8 : 2.9 Â± 0.4 ; n = 13 ). Pars postbulbosa very short, up to 35 ( 9 Â± 12 ; n = 15 ) long.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Prochristianella scholzi
n. sp.
from
Taeniura lymma
1 ( sensu Naylor et al . 2012). A . Partial specimen. B . Mature segment. C . Bulb. D . Scolex. E . Outlines of metabasal hooks. Abbreviations: cs, cirrus sac; gc, gland-cells; mg, Mehlisâ€™ gland; ov, ovary; rm, retractor muscle; sr, seminal receptacle; t, testis; vit, vitelline follicle.

FIGURE 10.
Prochristianella scholzi
n. sp.
from
Taeniura lymma
1 ( sensu Naylor et al . 2012). Tentacular armature. A . Basal and metabasal regions, external surface. B . Basal and metabasal regions, bothrial surface. C . Basal and metabasal regions, antibothrial surface; note opposing surface to ( B ) of the same tentacle.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Fully everted tentacles 450â€“610 ( 536 Â± 56 ; n = 9 ) long, with prominent basal swelling; diameter 24â€“25 ( 25 Â± 1 ; n = 3 ) at base, 33â€“38 ( 35 Â± 2 ; n = 4 ) at basal swelling, 25â€“28 ( 27 Â± 1 ; n = 4 ) in metabasal region, 25â€“26 ( 25 Â± 1 ; n = 3 ) distally. Metabasal armature heteroacanthous, heteromorphous; hooks hollow; hook rows consist of 10 hooks in posterior metabasal region (
Fig. 9
E), decrease to 9 hooks per principle row anteriorly; rows start on antibothrial surface of tentacle, terminate on bothrial surface (
Fig. 10
B, C); distinct space between hooks 1 and 1 â€™ (
Fig. 10
C); first four rows of principle rows with two smaller hooks posterior to hooks 1 ( 1 â€™) (
Fig. 10
C); hooks 1 ( 1 â€™) uncinate, with elongate base, 11â€“14 ( 13 Â± 1 ; n = 6 ) long, base 7â€“10 ( 8 Â± 1 ; n = 6 ) long; hooks 2 ( 2 â€™) larger, falcate, with narrower base, 12â€“15 ( 14 Â± 1 ; n = 7 ) long, base 4â€“6 ( 5 Â± 1 ; n = 4 ) long; hooks 3 ( 3 â€™) slightly smaller, falcate, 12â€“15 ( 13 Â± 1 ; n = 9 ) long, base 4â€“6 ( 4 Â± 1 ; n = 9 ) long; hooks 4 ( 4 â€™) smaller, falcate, 8â€“10 ( 9 Â± 1 ; n = 5 ) long, base 3â€“4 ( 3 Â± 1 ; n = 5 ) long; hooks 5 ( 5 â€™) larger, falcate, 12â€“16 ( 14 Â± 1 ; n = 6 ) long, base 4 (n = 6 ) long; hooks 6 ( 6 â€™) smaller, spiniform, 5â€“6 ( 5 Â± 1 ; n = 6 ) long, base 2â€“3 ( 3 ; n = 6 ) long; hooks 7 ( 7 â€™) smaller, spiniform, 4â€“5 ( 4 ; n = 4 ) long, base 2 (n = 4 ) long; hooks 8 ( 8 â€™) spiniform, 4â€“5 ( 4 Â± 1 ; n = 3 ) long, base 2 (n = 3 ) long; hooks 9 ( 9 â€™) slightly smaller, spiniform, 3â€“4 ( 4 Â± 1 ; n = 2 ) long, base 2 (n = 2 ) long; hooks 10 ( 10 â€™) slightly smaller, spiniform, 3 (n = 2 ) long, base 2 (n = 2 ) long.

Characteristic basal armature present (
Fig. 10
Aâ€“C); first rows of hooks enlarged on bothrial surface, falcate, 13â€“14 ( 14 ; n = 2 ) long, base 4â€“6 ( 5 Â± 1 ; n = 2 ) long; basal hooks on antibothrial surface smaller, uncinate, 6â€“9 ( 7 Â± 1 ; n = 3 ) long, base 4â€“5 ( 4 Â± 1 ; n = 3 ) long; next 4â€“5 rows of hooks spiniform, bases reduced, 6â€“9 ( 7 Â± 1 ; n = 8 ) long; basal swelling with 5 rows of hooks; increasing in size towards enlarged billhook on bothrial surface (
Fig. 10
A, B); billhooks form single file (
Fig. 10
B), largest billhooks in second and third row on basal swelling, 7 (n = 2 ) long, base 3 (n = 2 ) long, height 8 (n = 2 ); hooks on antibothrial surface spiniform, become falcate to almost uncinate anteriorly (
Fig. 10
C); transition to metabasal armature occurs at about hook row 17 (
Fig. 10
A, B).

Segments acraspedote; first segments wider than long; first mature segments elongate, 170â€“320 ( 247 Â± 51 ; n = 8 ) long, 110â€“205 ( 147 Â± 37 ; n = 8 ) wide (
Fig. 9
A); late mature segments 985â€“2,020 ( 1,381 Â± 336 ; n = 8 ) long, 130â€“230 ( 174 Â± 38 ; n = 8 ) wide (
Fig. 9
B); genital pores unilateral, in posterior half of segment (
Fig. 9
A, B); cirrus sac oval to sub-circular, thick-walled, 68â€“105 ( 86 Â± 13 ; n = 6 ) long, 70â€“100 ( 88 Â± 12 ; n = 6 ) wide; internal and external vesicles absent; cirrus unarmed. Testes arranged in two columns, anterior to ovary, in intervascular space, 53â€“71 ( 62 Â± 5 ; n = 14 ) in number, 41â€“57 ( 48 Â± 5 ; n = 14 ) anterior to genital pore, 12â€“18 ( 15 Â± 2 ; n = 14 ) posterior to genital pore, 48â€“63 ( 52 Â± 4 ; n = 17 ) long, 33â€“39 ( 35 Â± 2 ; n = 17 ) wide (
Fig. 9
B). Vagina thin-walled, enters genital atrium from posterior aspect; seminal receptacle c. 20 (n = 2 ) in diameter; ovary at posterior extremity of segment, bilobed in dorso-ventral view; ovarian lobes elongate, 183â€“258 ( 207 Â± 26 ; n = 8 ) long, 29â€“40 ( 33 Â± 4 ; n = 8 ) wide (
Fig. 9
B); Mehlisâ€™ gland present between ovarian lobes, 25â€“38 ( 30 Â± 6 ; n = 4 ) in diameter; vitelline follicles circumcortical, 20â€“23 ( 21 Â± 1 ; n = 10 ) long, 13â€“15 ( 14 Â± 1 ; n = 10 ) wide; uterus tubular, median, extends to anterior extremity of segment; uterine pore not observed.

Gravid segments 1,655â€“1,980 ( 1,845 Â± 169 ; n = 3 ) long, 175â€“305 ( 227 Â± 69 ; n = 3 ) wide; uterus extends to anteriormost extremity; cirrus sac sub-circular, 118 (n = 1 ) long, 108 (n = 1 ) wide; ovarian lobes 155â€“160 ( 158 Â± 4 ; n = 2 ) long, 36â€“38 ( 37 Â± 1 ; n = 2 ) wide; vitelline follicles 30â€“38 ( 35 Â± 2 ; n = 10 ) long, 25â€“30 ( 27 Â± 2 ; n = 10 ) wide.

Remarks: The present specimens are allocated to the genus
Prochristianella
, since they possess the typical, generic characteristics. The most significant features of this species are the smooth scolex, thick-walled bulbs with very few, tiny gland-cells, unilateral genital pores and a tentacular armature with enlarged basal hooks, rows of billhooks on the basal swelling and 10 hooks per half spiral row, decreasing in number to 9 hooks per row further anteriorly. The principle hook rows in the metabasal region have small hooks 4 ( 4 â€™), as described above for
P. kostadinovae
, which represents the most similar species within the genus.
Prochristianella scholzi
n. sp.
differs from
P. kostadinovae
in its possession of enlarged basal hooks, two additional hooks posterior to hooks 1 ( 1 â€™) in the most proximal part of the metabasal armature, smaller hooks 1 ( 1 â€™)â€“ 6 ( 6 â€™), hooks 2 ( 2 â€™) and 3 ( 3 â€™) without a recurved tip, a much wider basal swelling than the remainder of the tentacle and a transition into the metabasal armature at about hook row 17 . Moreover,
P. scholzi
n. sp.
has smaller bothria, Mehlisâ€™gland and vitelline follicles, but much more elongated ovarian lobes.
Prochristianella scholzi
n. sp.
is described from stingrays of the genus
Taeniura MÃ¼ller & Henle
from three localities in Sabah (Malaysian Borneo) and East Kalimantan (Indonesian Borneo).
